PSY101.name: Introductory Psychology
PSY101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY101.description: Mind and behavior from biological, individual, and social perspectives. Scientific and professional aspects of psychology.

PSY200.name: Cognitive Psychology
PSY200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY200.description: Concepts, theories, methods, and research findings in human information processing. Attention, perception, memory, problem solving, decision making, and language comprehension and production.

PSY209.name: Brain and Behavior
PSY209.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY209.description: Relation of structure and function of the nervous system to the biological bases of behavior.

PSY235.name: Social Psychology
PSY235.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY235.description: Major topics, theories, and research findings in social psychology, particularly as viewed from a psychological perspective.

PSY236.name: Personality
PSY236.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY236.description: Theories of personality, assessment techniques, and research on personality functioning and individual differences in interpersonal behavior. Emphasis on normal behavior.

PSY238.name: Developmental Psychology: Lifespan
PSY238.description: Growth and decline across the human lifespan. Physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development from conception to death.

PSY244.name: Developmental Psychology: Infancy Through Childhood
PSY244.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY244.description: Physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development from infancy through childhood.

PSY255.name: Industrial and Organizational Psychology
PSY255.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY255.description: Recruitment, selection, and training of personnel. Performance appraisal, leader behavior, worker attitudes and behavior, communication, group organization, and processes in the workplace.

PSY270.name: Community Psychology
PSY270.description: Theory and research in community psychology. Prevention, social change, dissemination models, empowerment, and measurement models.

PSY280.name: Abnormal Psychology
PSY280.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY280.description: Theory and research on dynamics, characteristics, and treatment of psychological disorders. Therapies and theories of prevention.

PSY292.name: Special Topics in Psychology
PSY292.description: Special topics in psychology proposed by faculty to supplement regular course offerings.

PSY295.name: Data Analysis in Psychological Research
PSY295.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY295.description: Descriptive and inferential statistics as applied to the analysis of psychological research. Measurement, control, and research design with psychological variables. Data analysis. Interpreting research findings. Relations between research and theory.
PSY295.prerequisite: {{((MTH 103) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test ) and (MTH 101 or MTH 102 or MTH 114 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or MTH 152H or STT 200 or STT 201)} or MTH 116} and PSY 101

PSY301.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
PSY301.description: Neural basis of human cognitive functions. Investigative methods for understanding the relationship of brain activity and behavior.

PSY310.name: Psychology and Biology of Human Sexuality
PSY310.description: Sexual behavior from biological, psychological and neuroscience perspectives. Sexual differentiation of the body. Role of hormones in development and reproduction in humans and other animals. Human sexual orientation. Fertility and contraception. Sexual disorders. Sexually transmitted diseases.
PSY310.prerequisite: (PSY 101 or concurrently) and ((BS 161 or concurrently) or (BS 162 or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently) or (LB 145 or concurrently) or (BS 181H or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently))

PSY316.name: Children's Exposure to Domestic Violence: Promoting Resiliency
PSY316.description: Prevalence, context and impact of domestic abuse on children. Strategies for promoting resiliency.

PSY317.name: Sexual Assault: Context, Interventions and Prevention
PSY317.description: Nature and context of adult sexual assault in the United States. Current interventions and prevention efforts.

PSY318.name: Gender-Based Violence Across the Lifespan
PSY318.description: Dynamics, risk factors, and community responses to gender-based violence across the lifespan.

PSY320.name: Health Psychology
PSY320.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY320.description: Social, psychological, and biological factors affecting health, illness, and use of health services. Stress and coping processes, lifestyles, and illness management.

PSY333.name: The Neurobiology of Food Intake and Overeating
PSY333.description: Physiological and neurological mechanisms that drive food intake and overeating. Vulnerabilities to obesity.

PSY339.name: Psychology of Women
PSY339.description: Development and implications of sex-typed behavior and sex differences. Women's decisions about and experiences of menstruation, sexuality, motherhood, relationships, achievement, employment, retirement.

PSY342.name: Stereotypes, Prejudice, and Discrimination
PSY342.description: Cognitive processes in stereotyping. Contribution of affect and motivation to the linkages among stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination.

PSY371.name: Psychological Innovations and Research I
PSY371.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY371.description: First course of two-semester sequence. Theoretical and technical background and direct involvement in a major psychological innovation or research project.

PSY372.name: Psychological Innovations and Research II
PSY372.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY372.description: Second course of a two-course sequence. Theoretical and technical background and direct involvement in a major psychological innovation or research project

PSY381.name: Internship Training in Psychology
PSY381.description: Theoretical and practical background to engage in effective internship delivery.

PSY382.name: Internship in Psychology
PSY382.description: Internship employing knowledge and skills acquired in psychology courses.

PSY395.name: Research Design and Measurement in Psychological Research
PSY395.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY395.description: Validity and reliability concepts in psychological measurement and causal inference. Experimental design in psychological research.

PSY401.name: Expertise and Skill (W)
PSY401.description: Contemporary models of expertise and skill acquisition and the role of basic cognitive abilities and capacities in complex performance.
PSY401.prerequisite: PSY 200 and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY402.name: Sensation and Perception (W)
PSY402.description: Biological and psychological approaches to the study of the extraction, representation, and interpretation of sensory information. Review of major methodologies. Emphasis on vision.
PSY402.prerequisite: (PSY 200 or PSY 209) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY405.name: History of Modern Psychology (W)
PSY405.description: Themes, periods, and contributions of the leading psychologists. Psychological systems such as behaviorism, cognition, and psychoanalysis. Evolution of psychological concepts. Social context.
PSY405.prerequisite: (PSY 295) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PSY405.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Psychology.

PSY409.name: Psychobiology of Behavioral Development (W)
PSY409.description: Biological approaches to the understanding of behavioral development in human and non-human animals. Role of the nervous system in this process.
PSY409.prerequisite: (PSY 209 or NEU 300 or IBIO 405) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY410.name: Neuroscience of Learning and Memory (W)
PSY410.description: Neural mechanisms responsible for learning and memory.
PSY410.prerequisite: (PSY 200 or PSY 209 or PSY 301 or NEU 300 or IBIO 405) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY411.name: Hormones and Behavior (W)
PSY411.description: Current research on biological mechanisms that control motivation in humans and non-human species.
PSY411.prerequisite: (PSY 209 or NEU 300 or IBIO 405) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY413.name: Laboratory in Behavioral Neuroscience (W)
PSY413.description: Theory and laboratory experience in the study of behavioral neuroscience. Relationship among hormones, brain, and behavior.
PSY413.prerequisite: (PSY 209 or IBIO 402) and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY424.name: Child and Family Psychopathology (W)
PSY424.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY424.description: Description, etiology, and developmental patterns of behavior problems of children, adolescents, and their families. Child and family interventions.
PSY424.prerequisite: (PSY 295) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PSY424.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Psychology.

PSY444.name: Developmental Psychology: Adolescence Through Youth (W)
PSY444.description: Theory and research in physical, cognitive, emotional, and social development from puberty to early adulthood.
PSY444.prerequisite: (PSY 101 and PSY 244 and PSY 295) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PSY455.name: Advanced Topics in Organizational Psychology (W)
PSY455.description: Applied research related to human resource issues in work organizations. Selection, training, motivation, leadership, and organizational change.
PSY455.prerequisite: (PSY 255 and PSY 295) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PSY455.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Psychology or in the Bachelor of Arts in Interdisciplinary Studies in Social Science Major or in the Bachelor of Science in Interdisciplinary Studies in Social Science Major.

PSY463.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
PSY463.description: Cognitive processing of information by animals, humans, and computers. Relevant issues in philosophy, linguistics, psychology, neurophysiology, and artificial intelligence.

PSY490.name: Special Problems in Psychology
PSY490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY490.description: Students work under direction of a faculty member on an experimental, theoretical, or applied problem.
PSY490.restrictions: Approval of department; application required. Students are limited to a combined total of 12 credits in PSY 490 and PSY 491.

PSY491.name: Participation in Psychological Project
PSY491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY491.description: Students participate in a psychological project under direction of a faculty member.
PSY491.restrictions: Approval of department; application required. Students are limited to a combined total of 12 credits in PSY 490 and PSY 491.

PSY492.name: Advanced Topics in Psychology
PSY492.description: Advanced topics proposed by faculty to supplement regular course offerings.

PSY493.name: Issues in Psychology (W)
PSY493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY493.description: Current information, research, and practice in psychology.
PSY493.prerequisite: PSY 101 and ((PSY 295 or STT 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

PSY497H.name: Senior Honors Project
PSY497H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY497H.description: Capstone experience in psychology for honors student's project thesis.

PSY498H.name: Development of Research Proposal
PSY498H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY498H.description: Independent research with faculty supervision. Literature survey, naturalistic observation, and experimental investigation. Preparation of the proposal for the Senior Honors Thesis.

PSY499H.name: Senior Honors Thesis
PSY499H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY499H.description: Continuation of independent research with faculty supervision. Completion of senior honor thesis.

PSY801.name: Sensation and Perception
PSY801.description: Biological, psychological, and computational approaches to the study of extraction, representation, and interpretation of sensory information. Review of major methodologies. Emphasis on vision.
PSY801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY802.name: Basic Cognitive Processes
PSY802.description: Advanced exploration of methods used to study human cognition as applied to sensory processes, perception, attention, memory, and control of action
PSY802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or in the Cognitive Science Specialization or approval of department.

PSY803.name: Higher Order Cognitive Processes
PSY803.description: Advanced exploration of inductive and deductive reasoning, categorization, analogy, decision making, and problem solving
PSY803.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or in the Cognitive Science Specialization or approval of department.

PSY804.name: Molecular and Developmental Neurobiology
PSY804.description: Nervous system specific gene transcription and translation. Maturation, degeneration, plasticity, and repair in the nervous system.
PSY804.restrictions: Open to graduate students in Neuroscience major.

PSY809.name: Developmental Psychobiology
PSY809.description: Basic principles of neural development over the life span.
PSY809.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY811.name: Advanced Behavioral Neuroscience
PSY811.description: Biological mechanisms involved in learning and memory, motivated behaviors, biological rhythms, and psychopathologies.
PSY811.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major or Neuroscience major.

PSY815.name: Quantitative Research Design and Analysis in Psychology
PSY815.description: Experimental and non-experimental research designs. Analysis of variance and multiple regression.
PSY815.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY818.name: Psychometric Theory and Test Construction
PSY818.description: Classical and item response theory approaches to test development. Validation of measures.
PSY818.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY831.name: Personality Assessment
PSY831.description: Psychometrics, clinical techniques, multimethod assessment measures including the MMPI, NEO-PI-R, PAI, TAT, IIP, Rorschach.
PSY831.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY834.name: Social Psychology
PSY834.description: Classic and contemporary theoretical and empirical issues in social psychology.
PSY834.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY835.name: Research Methods: Interpersonal and Individual Behavior
PSY835.description: Strategies and tactics for conducting systematic empirical research on complex human functioning. Social and clinical phenomena.
PSY835.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY836.name: Personality Psychology
PSY836.description: Classic and contemporary theoretical and empirical issues in personality psychology.
PSY836.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major or approval of department.

PSY837.name: Social Cognition
PSY837.description: Research on cognitive mediators of social behavior and life outcomes. Attribution, person perception, stereotyping, attitudes, and social memory.
PSY837.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major or approval of department.

PSY838.name: Interpersonal Behavior and Relationships
PSY838.description: Theory and empirical research on interpersonal processes. Social comparison, social support, self-evaluation, relationship development and dissolution, attraction, and love.
PSY838.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major or approval of department.

PSY839.name: Systems Neuroscience
PSY839.description: Anatomy, pharmacology, and physiology of multicellular neural systems. Sensory, motor, autonomic, and chemo-regulatory systems in vertebrate brains.
PSY839.restrictions: Open to graduate students or human medicine students or osteopathic medicine students in the College of Natural Science or in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine or in the College of Social Science or in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

PSY841.name: Evolutionary Psychology
PSY841.description: The nature and causes of human social behavior and cognition. The evolution, function, strategic logic, and psychology of topics such as family and friendship, sexuality and romance, aggression and warfare, cooperation and conflict, politics, religion, and moral judgment.
PSY841.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY843.name: Stereotyping, Prejudice and Discrimination
PSY843.description: Major theoretical perspectives and methodological issues surrounding the psychology of stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination within modern society.
PSY843.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY852.name: Cognitive and Neuropsychological Assessment
PSY852.description: Instruction in basic administration and interpretation of cognitive and neuropsychological tests across the life span
PSY852.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY853.name: Behavior Disorders
PSY853.description: Classification, description, and etiology of behavior disorders. Conceptual models, epidemiology, and review of major diagnostic classification systems.
PSY853.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY860.name: Industrial and Organizational Psychology
PSY860.description: Theory, research, and practice in organizational training, development, and behavior.
PSY860.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY863.name: Seminar in Cognitive Science
PSY863.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY863.description: Contemporary issues, problems, theories, and data in cognitive science, seen from a variety of perspectives

PSY864.name: Personnel Selection
PSY864.description: Methods and research in personnel selection. Job analysis, performance appraisal, and development of predictors. Evaluating validity, reliability, and utility of selection procedures.
PSY864.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major.

PSY865.name: Research Methods in Applied Psychology
PSY865.description: Human resource issues and applied research. Measurement problems and issues. Planning, conducting, analyzing, and disseminating applied research.
PSY865.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology major.

PSY867.name: Nature and Practice of Cognitive Science
PSY867.description: Survey of how different disciplines explore the cognitive processes underlying intelligent behavior.

PSY870.name: Ecological-Community Psychology
PSY870.description: Theory, methodology and research in experimental ecological approaches to community psychology. Identifying researchable problems and funding. The dynamics of research teams.
PSY870.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY871.name: History and Theory in Ecological-Community Psychology
PSY871.description: Theoretical perspectives, contemporary problems, philosophies of science, and ethical issues facing the ecological psychologist.
PSY871.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY872.name: Field Research in Psychology
PSY872.description: Unobtrusive, observational, and interview measures. Policy analysis, proposal preparation, and research design.
PSY872.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY873.name: Methods and Practice of Community Engagement I
PSY873.description: Entry and operational issues in community interventions and engaged research. Group dynamics, models of practice, and community engagement issues.
PSY873.restrictions: Open to master''s students or doctoral students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY874.name: Methods and Practice of Community Engagement II
PSY874.description: Issues in executing and completing community engaged research projects. Community engagement issues including ethics, communication, and project closure.
PSY874.restrictions: Open to master''s students or doctoral students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY880.name: Foundations of Evaluation Practice
PSY880.description: History, professional roles and contexts, practice standards, and central theories of program evaluation
PSY880.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY881.name: Evaluation Design
PSY881.description: Fundamentals of designing formative and summative evaluations
PSY881.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY882.name: Evaluation Data Collection Methods
PSY882.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY883.name: Statistics for Evaluators I
PSY883.description: Quantitative evaluation data preparation and management. Descriptive and inferential statistics, including correlation and regression and their application to evaluation data. Interpreting and reporting statistics for evaluation audiences.
PSY883.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY884.name: Qualitative and Mixed Method Evaluation Methods
PSY884.description: Qualitative and mixed method designs and analytic techniques for program evaluation
PSY884.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY885.name: Communicating and Reporting
PSY885.description: Communicating and reporting program evaluation activities and findings. Generating and communicating recommendations. Techniques to facilitate deliberative dialogue about evaluation findings. Written, verbal, and listening skills.
PSY885.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY886.name: Evaluation Practicum Preparation
PSY886.description: Identifying potential placements. Resume and cover letter development. Interviewing skills and establishing a practicum contract.
PSY886.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY887.name: Statistics for Evaluators II
PSY887.description: Inferential statistics, including t-tests, analysis of variance, and non-parametric statistics and their application to evaluation data. Handling missing data, power analysis, and other statistical tools for evaluators.
PSY887.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY888.name: Evaluation Management
PSY888.description: Evaluation project management, budgeting, and quality assurance. Professional job search skills.
PSY888.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY889.name: Evaluation Practicum
PSY889.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
PSY889.description: Supervised practicum placement in a professional evaluation setting. Integration and application of theories, methods, and skills in evaluation practice.
PSY889.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY890.name: Special Problems in Psychology
PSY890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY890.description: Supervised student research on an experimental, theoretical, or applied problem.
PSY890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY891.name: Special Topics in Psychology
PSY891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY891.description: Supervised student engagement in an experimental, theoretical or applied topic.
PSY891.restrictions: Open to graduate students. Approval of department.

PSY899.name: Master's Thesis Research
PSY899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY926.name: Scientific and Professional Ethics
PSY926.description: Ethical issues in human and animal research. Ethical decisions involving issues of gender, ethnicity, and cultural diversity in psychological practice.
PSY926.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY930.name: Social, Cognitive, and Affective Neuroscience
PSY930.description: The neural mechanisms of social, cognitive, and affective/motivational processes. Theory, research, and methodology concerns.
PSY930.restrictions: Open to graduate students or master's students or doctoral students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY952.name: Psychodynamic Theory, Research and Intervention Across the Life Span
PSY952.description: Psychodynamic theories. Research on psychodynamic theoretical concepts and interventions. Intervention concepts, techniques, and types.
PSY952.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY954.name: Cognitive-Behavioral Theory, Research, and Intervention Across the Life Span
PSY954.description: Theories, techniques, and empirical bases of behavioral and cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy.
PSY954.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY956.name: Child and Adolescent Assessment and Treatment
PSY956.description: Effectiveness of assessment and treatment of child and adolescent psychopathology as well as psychotherapeutic clinical decision-making. Evidenced-based models of assessment and treatment strategies.
PSY956.restrictions: Open to master''s students or doctoral students in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

PSY961.name: Training and Organizational Development
PSY961.description: Theory and research on identification, development, and evaluation of training activities in organizations. Analysis of organizational functioning and change.
PSY961.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY962.name: Work Motivation and Job Satisfaction
PSY962.description: General theories of human motivation, attitudes, and affect. Specific theories of work motivation and job satisfaction.
PSY962.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY970.name: Advanced Topics in Ecological and Community Psychology
PSY970.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY970.description: Contemporary ecological and community psychology issues. Program evaluation, systems analysis. Empowerment, social support, and homelessness.
PSY970.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY992.name: Seminar in Psychology
PSY992.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY992.description: Theoretical and research topics in psychology.
PSY992.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY994.name: Practicum
PSY994.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PSY994.description: Clinical assessment, consultation, and psychotherapy. Supervised experience in assessment, consultation, and psychotherapy with adults, families, and children. Didactic seminar in related theory and research.
PSY994.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Psychology.

PSY999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
PSY999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PSY999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Psychology.
